messages.content: Text created/updated with CEFR level A2

Text saved: "Potentially Hazardous Asteroids" are rocks in space. They could be dangerous.

These rocks can come close to Earth. They can come inside 7.5 million kilometres. NASA has a map of 1,400 of these rocks. We think they will not be a danger. This is for the next 100 years. NASA has tools now. They can watch these rocks. They can guess if a rock will hit Earth. If a rock is coming, they can send two things. These things can stop the rock.
Feedback received: Grade 3/10 - FAIL

metadata.feedback_text: FAIL: Meaning Preservation Failure. The MeaningBERT score of 0.6455 is significantly below the required 0.75. This indicates a substantial loss of the original text's core message and nuance. Specific issues include: 1. The definition of 'Potentially Hazardous Asteroids' is incomplete. The original specifies 'within 7.5 million kilometres of Earth's orbit', but your version omits 'of Earth's orbit', which is a critical detail for defining these objects. 2. The statement 'none of which are expected to be a threat' (NASA's official expectation) is diluted to 'We think they will not be a danger', changing the authoritative source of the information. 3. The concept of 'two defence solutions' is simplified to 'two things. These things can stop the rock', losing the specific implication of planned, strategic solutions. These omissions and shifts in emphasis collectively degrade the fidelity of the message. Suggestion: Rephrase the definition of PHAs to include 'of Earth's orbit'. Restore the agency of NASA's expectation regarding threats. Use more precise language for 'defence solutions' while maintaining A2 simplicity.

NASA has a map of 1,400 of these rocks. NASA says they will not be a danger. This is for the next 100 years.
NASA has tools now. They can watch these rocks. They can guess if a rock will hit Earth.
If a rock is coming, NASA has two plans. These plans can stop the rock.

metadata.feedback_text: FAIL: Meaning Preservation Failure. The MeaningBERT score of 0.6941 is below the required 0.75. The core meaning of the definition of 'Potentially Hazardous Asteroids' has been diluted. The original text precisely defines them as 'rocks close enough to pass within 7.5 million kilometres of Earth's orbit', directly linking the specific proximity to Earth's orbit as the reason for their 'potentially hazardous' classification. Your version fragments this into multiple sentences: 'They come within 7.5 million kilometres of Earth's path. This means they are very close to Earth. These rocks can be dangerous.' This breaks the direct causal link and precision of the original definition, losing the nuance that the specific orbital proximity *is* the hazard, rather than just a characteristic followed by a separate statement of danger. The simplification has resulted in a loss of the original's precise semantic content.

NASA has a map of 1,400 of these rocks. NASA says they will not be a danger. This is for the next 100 years.
NASA has tools now. They can watch these rocks. They can guess if a rock will hit Earth.
If a rock is coming, NASA has two plans. These plans can stop the rock.
